awd_titl_txt: GP-EXTRA: Increasing Minorities in the Atmospheric
awd_abstract_narration:
Jackson State University (JSU) is a research intensive Historically Black College and University (HBCU) and the first of only two HBCUs in the southeast U.S. with an Atmospheric Science program. JSU is the largest producer of African American B.S. degrees in Atmospheric Science (NCES, 2014). JSU has a four-year graduation rate of nineteen percent, which suggests either students are not being well-prepared prior to college or there is a greater need for support services for incoming students. Although graduation rates are low, 75% of HBCU students are low-income students and the HBCU graduation rates of these students outperforms those at all other institutions (USBE&IT, 2015). In 2014,  understanding the need to develop students with career relevant competencies and skills, Jackson Public Schools created the Academy of Scientific Innovations at Provine High School with a division in atmospheric science. The introduction of the division was in direct response from our Associate Dean and the fact that Provine is within a mile from JSU Meteorology Program. Through this program students will: increase their understanding of the interdisciplinary nature of the geosciences; acquire hands-on geoscience teaching experience; and be exposed to possible careers in the geosciences (including teaching); while acquiring real-world, geoscience workforce skills. The goal of the project is to establish a geoscience pipeline in the high school to increase the number of students in geoscience disciplines, and thus the diversity of the geoscience workforce. 

Increasing Minorities in the Atmospheric Sciences through the Geoscience Experiences (IMAGE) project is a three year partnership between the Jackson State University (JSU) Department of Physics, Atmospheric Science and Geosciences (DPAGS) and Provine High School. The project also collaborates with the National Weather Service offices in Shreveport, LA and Memphis, TN and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration?s National Weather Service?s Operations Division. The project leverages JSU?s demographic and institutional services to research, assess, and evaluate the effectiveness of a multilayered, academic year experience to increasing the number and diversity of students within the geosciences. The program targets a cohort of pre-college, first-year, transfer students and undergraduate geoscience majors. The cohorts will be supported academically, socially and professionally via a series of effective and evidence-based strategies including a summer bridge program; a mentored geoscience teaching experience; and internships. These activities will be aimed at achieving the program?s goals of increasing the number and diversity of STEM students, preparing students well to participate in science for tomorrow, and improving students' STEM learning outcomes. The program will test the effectiveness of preparatory courses, tutoring, student services support, and undergraduate research experiences on the target audience to facilitate students? academic and social integration during their critical transition stage into a four year college.

por.por_cntn:
IMAGE activities officially began June 16, 2017, with the preparation and planning of the inaugural IMAGE/CPAS symposium. At the onset, two undergraduate assistants were hired to assist in planning the interactive activities for student engagement. The goal of the symposium was to act as a recruiting event for potential meteorology students and upcoming participants for the summer bridge program. Ultimately, we wanted expose students to the meteorology programs at Jackson State, and to share with them the perspectives of other current and alumni students at various stages in their meteorological careers. It was also a great opportunity to allow current students to showcase their summer research as part of their professional development. Over the span of two years, we interacted with 165 students from Jackson Public Schools and Bard Early College out of New Orleans, Louisiana. We invited speakers and from the National Weather Service and the National Center for Environmental Protection.

In addition to the symposium, IMAGE hosted a summer bridge program, the most impactful piece of the project. A total of nine high school students and five undergraduate assistants, participated in the summer bridge during the summers of 2018 and 2019. The students underwent a week-long intensive summer school covering meteorology topics, such as precipitation, clouds, thunderstorms, tornados, etc. Along with those topics, students were given worksheets to help them comprehend and dissect scientific word problems while using mathematical principles. Despite the initial hesitance, the students begin to appreciate the value in this activity and soon started to compete amongst each other. Most of all, we adopted an “each one, teach one” mentality, where students who understood the topic, respectfully helped their peers work through the assignment. To ensure that no one was left behind, the students were given daily writing assignments to assess what they learned the previous day and topics they did not quite understand. 

Also, during the first week, the Observing Program Leader at the Jackson National Weather Service (NWS) Office, Latrice Maxie spoke to the students about weather instrumentation, and instructed them on how to take data from the campus weather stations and log it to the NWS observations database. The students were required to log daily measurements of temperature and precipitation to the NWS observation database. The students also underwent a brief training on forecasting by NWS Journeymen Meteorologist John P. Moore III and worked in teams to give daily forecasts for the duration of the program. In addition to the classroom topics and hands on activities, the students received basic training using ArcGIS to analyze historic tornado data for the state of Mississippi. On the last day of the program, the students presented a group project, demonstrating their analysis. Overall, the highlight for the students, were the field trips to the Jackson-NWS and WLBT news station. The students toured the NWS facility and learned about the different capabilities and services offered. At WLBT the students had the opportunity to conduct a news report with the help of Meteorologist Patrick Ellis and learned how difficult it was to give a weather forecast (without notes) using a green screen. The students were also able to participate in the WIFI townhall meeting between the National Weather Service, Mississippi Emergency Management Agency, and local emergency management agencies, discussing the high impact weather events for the year. 

Due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, we were unable to host the usual activities such as the high school summer bridge program and the symposium. Instead, all IMAGE activities were focused on current undergraduate meteorology students, via a study hall. The study hall consisted of weekly hour-long meetings focusing on professional development, homework help, and talks with current meteorology industry professionals of color. In addition to weekly study halls, the IMAGE program partnered with the National Institute of Standards and Technology to support a student for an internship. The remainder of the project period focused on supporting incoming freshman students to help the adjust to college life and alleviate some of their financial burden.

Since the inception of the program, the impact of IMAGE has been widespread amongst student success during and beyond their undergraduate careers. A couple of the primary goals was to “foster university-industry partnerships to provide STEM workplace experience” and “and prepare minorities at an HBCU so as to increase the number and diversity of the geoscience workforce.” IMAGE helped to recruit two students into the Meteorology program at Jackson State University (JSU), one of which is preparing to graduate Spring 2023. A total of three students at JSU supported through the IMAGE professional and academic development programs, secured jobs with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, two as NOAA Pathways Students (including the first recruit). Additionally, we had a student participant go on to teach physics at Provine High School.
